GNP of S. Korea Termed Dregs of Society 
     Pyongyang, December 29 (KCNA) -- Minju Joson today in a signed commentary brands the Grand National Party in south Korea as a group of betes-noires in connection with the publication of the results of investigation made into the illegal wiretapping by the Security Planning Board and the Intelligence Service in south Korea.
 It says: 
 The GNP is such group of betes-noires that just a little probe into its past is enough to dig out its hideous crimes. This is clearly proved by the cases of illegal wiretapping perpetrated by the Security Planning Board which sparked a big furor in south Korea for the past several months since July.
 The GNP group has kicked off quite a row while dastardly pulling up others instead of admitting and apologizing for the scandal since it was disclosed.
 The predecessors of the GNP resorted to such illegal wiretapping to fake up cases for suppressing those people and its political rivals that stood for independence, democracy and reunification.    
 The true aim sought by the GNP is to keep the crimes it has committed buried into oblivion and come to power again at any cost.    
 It is necessary to probe the truth behind every crime committed by GNP and sternly punish the criminals on behalf of the nation irrespective of the statute of limitations in order to prevent the dark era of fascism from coming to south Korea again, improve the inter-Korean relations by the concerted efforts of the Koreans and achieve the independent and peaceful reunification of Korea.

Floral Baskets and Congratulatory Letters to Kim Jong Il 
    Pyongyang, December 29 (KCNA) -- Leader Kim Jong Il was presented with floral baskets and congratulatory letters by the economic and commercial councilors' corps here and officials in charge of cultural and friendly relations of foreign embassies here on the occasion of the New Year Juche 95 (2006).
 They were conveyed to officials concerned by Gu Jinsheng, economic and commercial councilor of the Chinese embassy here, on behalf of the economic and commercial councilors' corps and by Ioan Dedean, councilor of the Romanian embassy here, on behalf of officials in charge of cultural and friendly relations on Dec. 29.
